However, due to <a href="National%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Association">NCAA</a> sanctions, they were ineligible for postseason play. Miami finished in second place based on the formula. However, due to likely pending NCAA sanctions from the <a href="2011%20University%20of%20Miami%20athletics%20scandal">Nevin Shapiro scandal</a>, the university's administration preemptively chose to forego post-season play for the second consecutive year. Had they played, it would have marked their only appearance in the ACC championship game, since joining the conference, in 2004. It would also have set up a rematch with <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a>, who had defeated the Hurricanes earlier in the season.
The Hurricanes compiled a 9–4 record in <a href="2013%20Miami%20Hurricanes%20football%20team">2013</a>. Golden's team came storming out of the gate, winning their first seven; a 34–6 win over in-state opponent <a href="Florida%20Atlantic%20Owls%20football">Florida Atlantic</a>, a 21–16 win over rival <a href="Florida%20Gators%20football">Florida</a>, a 77-7 thrashing of <a href="Football%20Championship%20Subdivision">FCS</a> opponent <a href="Savannah%20State%20Tigers%20football">Savannah State</a>, a 49–21 victory over <a href="South%20Florida%20Bulls%20football">South Florida</a>, a 45–30 win over <a href="Georgia%20Tech%20Yellow%20Jackets%20football">Georgia Tech</a>, a 27-23 close win over <a href="North%20Carolina%20Tar%20Heels%20football">North Carolina</a> and a 24-21 nail biter over <a href="Wake%20Forest%20Demon%20Deacons%20football">Wake Forest</a>. The Hurricanes suffered their first loss of the 2013 season on November 2, losing to No. 3 <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a> in a 41-14 thrashing. Miami dropped a second straight game by way of a 42–24 loss to <a href="Virginia%20Tech%20Hokies%20football">Virginia Tech</a> and a third consecutive loss to <a href="Duke%20Blue%20Devils%20football">Duke</a> in a 48-30 disappointment dropped the Hurricanes from a No. 7 national ranking to unranked in those three weeks. The Hurricanes were able to close out the regular season with two wins, defeating <a href="Virginia%20Cavaliers%20football">Virginia</a> 45-26 and <a href="Pittsburgh%20Panthers%20football">Pittsburgh</a> 41–31. Miami received a berth in the <a href="2013%20Russell%20Athletic%20Bowl">2013 Russell Athletic Bowl</a>, a game they lost to No. 18 <a href="Louisville%20Cardinals%20football">Louisville</a> in a 36-9 blowout. In October 2013, after an investigation spanning two and a half years, the NCAA announced that "the committee acknowledged and accepted the extensive and significant self-imposed penalties by the university." Therefore, no further bowl ban would be enforced. As a result, Miami was eligible to compete in ACC championship and BCS bowls for the 2013–14 season. However, the NCAA stripped Miami of nine scholarships over three years.
The Hurricanes went 6–7 in <a href="2014%20Miami%20Hurricanes%20football%20team">2014</a>. Miami kicked off the season with a 31–13 loss to No. 25 <a href="Louisville%20Cardinals%20football">Louisville</a> on September 1. Miami defeated <a href="Florida%20A%26amp%3BM%20Rattlers%20football">Florida A&M</a> 41-7 and <a href="Arkansas%20State%20Red%20Wolves%20football">Arkansas State</a> 41-20 over the next two weeks before losing to No. 24 <a href="Nebraska%20Cornhuskers%20football">Nebraska</a> by a score of 41–31. On September 27, the Hurricanes defeated <a href="Duke%20Blue%20Devils%20football">Duke</a> by a margin of 22–10. On October 4, <a href="Georgia%20Tech%20Yellow%20Jackets%20football">Georgia Tech</a> defeated Miami by a score of 28–17. Miami won their next three; winning 55–34 over <a href="Cincinnati%20Bearcats%20football">Cincinnati</a>, 30–6 over <a href="Virginia%20Tech%20Hokies%20football">Virginia Tech</a> and 47–20 over <a href="North%20Carolina%20Tar%20Heels%20football">North Carolina</a>. Golden's squad struggled to finish the season, losing their last four; a 30-26 letdown to archrival <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a>, a 30-13 disappointment to <a href="Virginia%20Cavaliers%20football">Virginia</a>, a 35–23 defeat at the hands of <a href="Pittsburgh%20Panthers%20football">Pittsburgh</a> in the regular season finale and a 24-21 close defeat in the <a href="2014%20Independence%20Bowl">2014 Independence Bowl</a> in <a href="Shreveport%2C%20Louisiana">Shreveport, Louisiana</a>, to <a href="South%20Carolina%20Gamecocks%20football">South Carolina</a>.
The Hurricanes finished 8–5 in <a href="2015%20Miami%20Hurricanes%20football%20team">2015</a>. By this time, many Miami fans had grown restless and irritated at the team's inconsistencies and began to call for Golden to be fired using different means, including flying airplanes over <a href="Hard%20Rock%20Stadium">Hard Rock Stadium</a> with various "Fire Al Golden" banners. The Hurricanes started the season with a 45–0 shutout of <a href="Bethune-Cookman%20Wildcats%20football">Bethune-Cookman</a> on September 5. A 44–20 win over <a href="Florida%20Atlantic%20Owls%20football">Florida Atlantic</a> and a 36–33 overtime victory over <a href="Nebraska%20Cornhuskers%20football">Nebraska</a> followed before the Hurricanes lost 34–23 to <a href="Cincinnati%20Bearcats%20football">Cincinnati</a> and 29–24 to No. 12 <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a>. Miami defeated <a href="Virginia%20Tech%20Hokies%20football">Virginia Tech</a> by a score of 30–20 on October 17 in what would be Al Golden's last win as Miami head coach. On October 25, 2015, the day after a 58–0 home loss to <a href="Clemson%20Tigers%20football">Clemson</a>, the worst defeat in school history, the university's athletic director, <a href="Blake%20James%20%28athletics%20director%29">Blake James</a>, announced Golden had been fired. Golden was 32–25 in his five seasons at Miami and led the program to bowl games in 2013 and 2014. <a href="Tight%20end">Tight end</a>s coach <a href="Larry%20Scott%20%28American%20football%29">Larry Scott</a> finished the season as interim head coach. In Scott's first game as interim head coach, the Hurricanes recorded a controversial win over <a href="Duke%20Blue%20Devils%20football">Duke</a>. The Hurricanes used eight <a href="lateral%20pass">laterals</a> (reminiscent of the <a href="The%20Play%20%28American%20football%29">1982 Cal-Stanford ending</a>) on a kickoff return with no time remaining to score the game-winning touchdown and stun the Blue Devils by a score of 30–27. However, video evidence showed the play should have been blown dead and not counted as a touchdown, as Miami players who possessed the ball on that play's knee were shown to be on the ground more than once. Although the outcome of the game couldn't be changed, the <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> subsequently suspended the game and replay officials for failing to catch the errors and make the correct call. On November 7, Miami defeated <a href="Virginia%20Cavaliers%20football">Virginia</a> by a score of 27–21. The next week, the Hurricanes lost to No. 17 <a href="North%20Carolina%20Tar%20Heels%20football">North Carolina</a> by a score of 59–21. Miami then defeated <a href="Georgia%20Tech%20Yellow%20Jackets%20football">Georgia Tech</a> 38-21 and <a href="Pittsburgh%20Panthers%20football">Pittsburgh</a> 29–24. The Hurricanes received a berth in the <a href="2015%20Sun%20Bowl">2015 Sun Bowl</a>, a game they lost to <a href="Washington%20State%20Cougars%20football">Washington State</a> by a score of 20–14.
Mark Richt era (2016–2018).
On December 4, 2015, former <a href="Georgia%20Bulldogs%20football">Georgia</a> head coach <a href="Mark%20Richt">Mark Richt</a> was named Miami's 24th head football coach. The hiring generated much excitement and was well-received and praised all across the country. Although he had recently been fired as head coach of the Bulldogs, Richt achieved great successes during his 15 years as Georgia head coach. His teams represented the SEC in three BCS bowl appearances with a record of 2–1, and finished in the top ten of the final AP Poll seven times (2002–2005, 2007, 2012, 2014). His 2008 team also finished in the top ten of the coaches poll. His Georgia teams averaged about nine wins per season, won two <a href="Southeastern%20Conference">Southeastern Conference</a> championship games and reached four more, reached bowl games each of his 15 seasons as head coach and sent many players to <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> playing careers. Richt had prior ties to the Miami football program, having played <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> for the Hurricanes under <a href="Lou%20Saban">Lou Saban</a> and <a href="Howard%20Schnellenberger">Howard Schnellenberger</a> from 1978 to 1982 and, despite being behind the likes of <a href="Jim%20Kelly">Jim Kelly</a>, <a href="Vinny%20Testaverde">Vinny Testaverde</a> and <a href="Bernie%20Kosar">Bernie Kosar</a> on the depth chart, amassed nearly 1,500 passing yards during his college playing career. Richt also served as offensive coordinator at <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a> from 1994 to 2000 under <a href="Bobby%20Bowden">Bobby Bowden</a>, overseeing an offense that was one of the most potent in the country, won two national championships, and produced two <a href="Heisman%20Trophy">Heisman Trophy</a> winners in <a href="Charlie%20Ward">Charlie Ward</a> and <a href="Chris%20Weinke">Chris Weinke</a>. Miami signed Richt to a five-year contract worth $4.1 million annually.
The Hurricanes improved to 9–4 in <a href="2016%20Miami%20Hurricanes%20football%20team">2016</a>. They began the season on September 3 by blowing out in-state <a href="Football%20Championship%20Subdivision">FCS</a> opponent <a href="Florida%20A%26amp%3BM%20Rattlers%20football">Florida A&M</a> 70–3. The next week, the Hurricanes defeated <a href="Florida%20Atlantic%20Owls%20football">Florida Atlantic</a> by a score of 38–10. After defeating <a href="Appalachian%20State%20Mountaineers%20football">Appalachian State</a> 45–10, Miami defeated <a href="Georgia%20Tech%20Yellow%20Jackets%20football">Georgia Tech</a> by a score of 35–21 to record their first <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> win under Richt. Then, the Hurricanes embarked upon a four-game losing streak, dropping games to No. 23 <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a> by a score of 20–19, <a href="North%20Carolina%20Tar%20Heels%20football">North Carolina</a> by a margin of 20–13, <a href="Virginia%20Tech%20Hokies%20football">Virginia Tech</a> by a count of 37-16 and <a href="Notre%20Dame%20Fighting%20Irish%20football">Notre Dame</a> to the tune of 30–27. The Hurricanes rebounded to win their last five games of the season; a 51-28 trouncing of <a href="Pittsburgh%20Panthers%20football">Pittsburgh</a>, a 34–14 victory over <a href="Virginia%20Cavaliers%20football">Virginia</a>, a 27–13 win over <a href="NC%20State%20Wolfpack%20football">NC State</a> and a 40–21 win over <a href="Duke%20Blue%20Devils%20football">Duke</a> with quarterback <a href="Brad%20Kaaya">Brad Kaaya</a> becoming Miami's all-time leading passer to close the regular season. On December 28, 2016, Richt led the Hurricanes to their first bowl win in 10 years, when they defeated No. 16 <a href="West%20Virginia%20Mountaineers%20football">West Virginia</a> in the <a href="2016%20Russell%20Athletic%20Bowl">2016 Russell Athletic Bowl</a> by a score of 31–14.
Miami finished 10–3 in <a href="2017%20Miami%20Hurricanes%20football%20team">2017</a>. The Hurricanes began the season on September 2, defeating in-state <a href="Football%20Championship%20Subdivision">FCS</a> opponent <a href="Bethune%E2%80%93Cookman%20Wildcats%20football">Bethune–Cookman</a> by a margin of 41–13. The Hurricanes were supposed to play <a href="Arkansas%20State%20Red%20Wolves%20football">Arkansas State</a> on September 9, but the game was canceled due to <a href="Hurricane%20Irma">Hurricane Irma</a> battering the state of <a href="Florida">Florida</a> that weekend. Although the game was to be played in <a href="Jonesboro%2C%20Arkansas">Jonesboro, Arkansas</a>, the University of Miami administration contended that it would be too difficult for the football team to safely travel in and out of Florida due to the intensity of the hurricane. When Miami refused to reschedule the game and pay the $650,000 they agreed to pay the Red Wolves, the Arkansas State University administration filed a lawsuit seeking the payment. As a result of the cancellation, Miami only played 11 regular season games in 2017 as opposed to the usual 12. Miami also rescheduled their game against <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a> from September 16 to October 7 due to the aftermath of the hurricane. On September 23, Miami played its second game of the season, defeating <a href="Toledo%20Rockets%20football">Toledo</a> by a score of 52–30. After a 31–6 victory over <a href="Duke%20Blue%20Devils%20football">Duke</a>, Richt's team defeated archrival <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a> by a score of 24–20. After a 25-24 nail biting win over <a href="Georgia%20Tech%20Yellow%20Jackets%20football">Georgia Tech</a>, the Hurricanes defeated <a href="Syracuse%20Orange%20football">Syracuse</a> by a margin of 27–19. On October 28, Miami defeated <a href="North%20Carolina%20Tar%20Heels%20football">North Carolina</a> by a score of 24–19. That was followed by a 28–10 victory over No. 13 <a href="Virginia%20Tech%20Hokies%20football">Virginia Tech</a>. On November 11, Richt's squad obliterated <a href="Notre%20Dame%20Fighting%20Irish%20football">Notre Dame</a> by a score of 41–8. After a 44–28 win over <a href="Virginia%20Cavaliers%20football">Virginia</a>, Miami suffered its first loss of the season in the regular season finale, falling to <a href="Pittsburgh%20Panthers%20football">Pittsburgh</a> by a margin of 24–14. In the <a href="2017%20ACC%20Championship%20Game">2017 ACC Championship Game</a>, Miami was obliterated by No. 1 <a href="Clemson%20Tigers%20football">Clemson</a> by a score of 38–3. The Hurricanes accepted a berth in the <a href="2017%20Orange%20Bowl">2017 Orange Bowl</a>, a game they lost to No. 6 <a href="Wisconsin%20Badgers%20football">Wisconsin</a> by a score of 34–24. On May 3, 2018, the University of Miami administration signed Richt to a five-year contract extension. Miami ended 2018 with another loss to Wisconsin, this time in the Pinstripe Bowl 35–3, finishing 7–6. On December 30, 2018, Richt abruptly announced his retirement from coaching.
Manny Diaz era (2019–2021).
On the same day Richt announced his retirement, Miami hired <a href="Manny%20Diaz%20%28American%20football%29">Manny Diaz</a> as their new head coach. Diaz compiled a 21–15 record in three seasons at the university. On December 6, 2021, in anticipation of hiring <a href="Oregon%20Ducks%20football">Oregon</a> head coach and Canes alumnus <a href="Mario%20Cristobal">Mario Cristobal</a> to replace him, Diaz was fired.

Rivalries.
Florida Cup.
Miami's traditional rivals are <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a> and <a href="Florida%20Gators%20football">Florida</a>. Since 2002, the <a href="Florida%20Cup">Florida Cup</a> has been awarded to the team that finishes with the best head-to-head record in years where Miami, Florida, and Florida State all face each other. Five Florida Cups have been awarded, with Miami winning the first three.
Florida State.
The <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a> rivalry dates to 1951, when the Hurricanes defeated the Seminoles 35–13 in their inaugural meeting. The schools have played every year since 1966, with Miami holding the all-time advantage, 33–30. Upon the conclusion of their 2003 regular-season schedules, the teams represented their respective conferences in the 2004 <a href="FedEx%20Orange%20Bowl">FedEx Orange Bowl</a> (Miami being the champions of the Big East, and Florida State being the champions of the ACC). Miami won the bowl game 16–14; it was the only time the schools have met in post-season football play. The 63 meetings between the teams of FSU and Miami eclipsed the rivalry between the Hurricanes and the Gators (from the <a href="University%20of%20Florida">University of Florida</a>) following their 2010 game; the series of games between UM and Florida is Miami's second-longest at 55 games.
During the 1980s and '90s, the series emerged as one of the premier rivalries in college football. Between 1983 and 2002, the Hurricanes and Seminoles combined to win 7 national championships and play in 14 bowl games with a national championship at stake. The 1988 game starred 57 future <a href="National%20Football%20League">NFL</a> pros on the combined rosters. Since 2004, the year Miami left the <a href="Big%20East%20Conference%20%281979%E2%80%932013%29">Big East Conference</a> to join the expanded 12-member <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a>, the universities have been conference foes, though they are placed in separate divisions within the conference. This alignment creates the potential for the two teams to meet for a second time in the <a href="ACC%20Championship%20Game">ACC Championship Game</a>, should each win their respective divisions in any particular season. Such a rematch has yet to happen after 14 years of ACC Championship Games, as of 2018.
The series has consistently drawn very high <a href="Nielsen%20ratings">television ratings</a> with the 2006 Miami–Florida State game being the most-watched college football game—regular-season or postseason—in <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a> history, and the 2009 and 1994 meetings being the second- and fifth-most watched regular season games, respectively.
The Miami Hurricanes lead the all-time series 33–30. The most recent meeting was in 2018 on October 6 when the Miami Hurricanes won 28–27.
Florida.
Miami's rivalry with <a href="Florida%20Gators%20football">Florida</a> dates back to 1938, making it the oldest rivalry among Florida's "Big Three" of Miami, Florida, and Florida State. The Hurricanes defeated the Gators, 19–7, in the first meeting between the geographic rivals. The Seminole War Canoe was carved in 1955 out of a cypress struck by lightning and was given to the winner of the annual football game. The canoe is meant to symbolize the fighting spirit of the Seminole people that is often on display during games between the Hurricanes and Gators. The canoe is now on permanent display at the University of Miami Sports Hall of Fame on the Coral Gables campus.
Miami holds the edge in the all-time series with a 29–26 record against Florida. The two schools met every year from 1944 until 1987, but have not played regularly since then. Florida canceled the annual series after the 1987 season, when the requirement of the <a href="Southeastern%20Conference">Southeastern Conference</a> for member schools to play eight conference games induced the University of Florida to fill out the non-conference portion of its schedule with teams that do not require a home-and-home arrangement, except for Florida State.
From 1986 to 2003, Miami won all six of the games between the schools, including victories in the 2001 <a href="Sugar%20Bowl">Sugar Bowl</a> and the 2004 <a href="Peach%20Bowl">Peach Bowl</a>. Florida snapped its 23-year drought against Miami with a 26–3 win over the Hurricanes in 2008. In 2019, the series resumed with Florida winning 24–20 in the <a href="Camping%20World%20Kickoff">Camping World Kickoff</a> in Orlando, Florida.
Virginia Tech.
The Hurricanes and Hokies first met on November 13, 1953, in Miami. The two teams have played annually since 1992, and the rivalry developed when the Hokies became a member of the Big East Conference for football in 1991. When the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) expanded in 2004, both Miami and Virginia Tech became members of the ACC. Both teams continue to compete annually as part of the ACC's Coastal Division. Miami and Virginia Tech have twice met in bowl games, the <a href="1966%20Liberty%20Bowl">1966 Liberty Bowl</a> and <a href="1981%20Peach%20Bowl%20%28January%29">1981 Peach Bowl</a>. Miami leads the series 22–15 through the 2019 season.
Nebraska.
The series with <a href="Nebraska%20Cornhuskers%20football">Nebraska</a> is tied at 6–6 as of 2018.
Facilities.
The <a href="Hard%20Rock%20Stadium">Hard Rock Stadium</a> plays host to the Hurricanes football team during their regular season. The stadium is located in <a href="Miami%20Gardens%2C%20Florida">Miami Gardens, Florida</a>, located approximately north of the UM's main <a href="Coral%20Gables%2C%20Florida">Coral Gables</a> campus. Hard Rock stadium is the home stadium of the <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a> of the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a>(NFL).
From 1937 through 2007, the team played its home games at the <a href="Miami%20Orange%20Bowl">Orange Bowl</a>, located in the <a href="Little%20Havana">Little Havana</a> section of <a href="Miami">Miami</a>. In the late 2000s, the City of Miami, the owner of the Orange Bowl, proposed to extensively renovate it. However, those plans fell by the wayside as the city focused on keeping the Marlins baseball team in town, forcing the university to threaten a move to Hard Rock Stadium if a plan to renovate the stadium was not in place within 45 days. When the city could not deliver on a renovation plan, the university's board of trustees, on the recommendation of UM President <a href="Donna%20Shalala">Donna Shalala</a>, approved the shift to Hard Rock Stadium on August 21, 2007.
At its inception, the program played at Tamiami Park and, later, Moore Park before moving to the then <a href="Miami%20Orange%20Bowl">Burdine Stadium</a> in 1937.
The team practices on-campus at the Greentree Practice Fields, which were named the College Football Field of the Year by the SportsTurf Managers Association in 2007. The Hecht Athletic Center, also located on-campus, serves as the program's training facility and is home to the football offices. In November 2010, the university announced a gift of five million dollars from the Ted and Todd Schwartz family foundation that would be used to build the Schwartz Center for Athletic Excellence. The facility caters to over 400 student athletes on the campus with a sports medicine facility, training room, and academic center. The facility also has features specifically designed for the football team:
In May 2017, the university broke ground on the new Carol Soffer Indoor Practice Facility. The $34 million facility was led by a $14 million gift from Miami billionaire Jeffrey Soffer, owner of the famed <a href="Fontainebleau%20Miami%20Beach">Fountainebleau Miami Beach</a>. The building exceeds 100,000 square feet and includes two turf fields that combine for 81,000-square feet. The indoor facility, located on the current football practice area, will also house a football operations center with a mezzanine level for the football coaches' offices and meeting rooms.
Records.
Winning streaks.
Miami also has two of the <a href="Longest%20NCAA%20Division%20I%20football%20winning%20streaks">longest winning streaks in NCAA Division I history</a>. From 2000 to 2003, Miami won 34 consecutive games, tying for sixth all-time. The streak started on September 23, 2000, with a 47–10 victory at <a href="West%20Virginia%20Mountaineers%20football">West Virginia</a> and ended on January 3, 2003, with a 31–24 double overtime loss to <a href="2002%20Ohio%20State%20Buckeyes%20football%20team">Ohio State</a> in the <a href="2003%20Fiesta%20Bowl">2003 Fiesta Bowl</a>. Miami also won 29 straight games from October 27, 1990, to January 1, 1993, good for 13th on the all-time list. That streak was snapped when the top-ranked Hurricanes were upset by second-ranked <a href="1993%20Alabama%20Crimson%20Tide%20football%20team">Alabama</a>, 34–13 in the <a href="1993%20Sugar%20Bowl">1993 Sugar Bowl</a>.
Miami owns the record for the longest home winning streak in NCAA history, winning 58 straight games at the Orange Bowl. The record streak began with a 38–0 shutout victory over Cincinnati on October 12, 1985, and ended with a 38–20 loss to Washington on September 24, 1994. The 58 game streak includes three Orange Bowl victories where Miami was the away team because of the Orange Bowl's tie to the Big 8 conference.
In addition to its own lengthy winning streaks, Miami has snapped four streaks of 20 games or more in its history. The only other school to snap four winning streaks of 20 or more games is <a href="Princeton%20Tigers%20football">Princeton</a>. In the <a href="1984%20Orange%20Bowl">1984 Orange Bowl</a>, Miami ended top-ranked <a href="Nebraska%20Cornhuskers%20football">Nebraska</a>'s 22-game winning streak and won its first national championship with a 31–30 victory. The Hurricanes halted top-ranked <a href="Oklahoma%20Sooners%20football">Oklahoma</a>'s 20-game streak and won their second national championship when they defeated the Sooners, 20–14, in the <a href="1988%20Orange%20Bowl">1988 Orange Bowl</a>. The Hurricanes ended top-ranked <a href="1989%20Notre%20Dame%20Fighting%20Irish%20football%20team">Notre Dame</a>'s 23-game winning streak with a 27–10 win on November 25, 1989. Miami also ended the 20-game winning streak of <a href="UCLA%20Bruins%20football">UCLA</a> when Miami defeated the third-ranked Bruins 49–45 on December 5, 1998.

Traditions.
Touchdown Tommy.
Touchdown Tommy is the cannon that is fired off when the team runs out of the tunnel, after every point that the Hurricanes score, and the conclusion of a victory. The cannon is kept by the <a href="Sigma%20Chi">Sigma Chi</a> fraternity's Cannon Master and fired off during the games by the senior brothers of Sigma Chi. Touchdown Tommy is the third oldest tradition at the University of Miami, after the <a href="Iron%20Arrow%20Honor%20Society">Iron Arrow Honor Society</a> and <a href="Sebastian%20the%20Ibis">Sebastian the Ibis</a>.
The Smoke.
One of the Hurricanes best-known traditions is the team's entrance scene. The team enters the field through a large cloud of white smoke billowing from its entrance tunnel, amid a tape of a hurricane blasting over the sound system. The smoke comes from fire extinguisher exhaust that billows from a series of pipes welded together by school transportation director Bob Nalette in the 1950s. The pipes were moved to Sun Life Stadium when the Hurricanes moved there in 2008.
Following Miami's rise to prominence in the 1980s, many high school, college and <a href="National%20Football%20League">NFL</a> teams over the last 25 years have copied this practice, and in 2001 <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> made a parody of it for a Saturday college football commercial.
Ring of Honor.
In 1997, the university established the 'Ring of Honor' as a way to honor outstanding players who have passed through the Hurricane football program. Members are selected by an anonymous advisory committee, the director of athletics and the head football coach. The names and jersey numbers of the inductees were displayed on the upper deck of the <a href="Miami%20Orange%20Bowl">Orange Bowl</a> (which has since been torn down). The inaugural class of included <a href="Jim%20Dooley">Jim Dooley</a>, <a href="Ted%20Hendricks">Ted Hendricks</a>, <a href="George%20Mira">George Mira</a>, and <a href="Vinny%20Testaverde">Vinny Testaverde</a>. Turnover Chain.
In 2017, the Miami Hurricanes began to award its "Turnover Chain," an honor that contains a 36-inch, 2.5-kilogram, 10-karat gold chain, with 900 orange and green sapphire stones arranged in a "U" that is 6.5 inches wide. It is presented during a game to any defensive player who forces a turnover.
Through the 11 regular-season games Miami played in 2017, the Hurricanes' defense created 29 turnovers (17 passes intercepted, 12 fumbles recovered), the third most in FBS football. During the same period, Miami gave up 12 turnovers (throwing 9 interceptions, and losing 3 fumbles); the net gain of 17 turnovers resulted in a margin of +1.55 per game. That figure represents the greatest margin in the nation this year, an achievement shared with <a href="2017%20UCF%20Knights%20football%20team">Central Florida</a>.
Miami Hurricanes in the NFL.
Many Miami players go on to play in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a>. The school holds multiple NFL draft related records: most first-round draft picks in a two-year period (11, 2003–2004); most first-round draft picks in a three-year period (15, 2002–2004); and most first-round picks in a four-year period (19, 2001–2004). From 1995 through 2008, Miami set an <a href="NFL%20Draft">NFL Draft</a> record by having at least one player selected in the first round of 14 consecutive drafts. The Hurricanes once had a streak of 149 consecutive regular season weeks where a former Hurricane scored a touchdown in an NFL game; the streak started in Week 15 of the 2002 NFL regular season and ended in Week 11 of the 2011 season. During the streak, 33 different former Hurricanes scored touchdowns and a total of 661 touchdowns were scored. Setting a new record for most players from one school, eleven former Hurricanes were selected to the <a href="2010%20Pro%20Bowl">2010 Pro Bowl</a>, which happened to take place at Miami's <a href="Sun%20Life%20Stadium">Sun Life Stadium</a>.

Controversies and scandals.
The <a href="University%20of%20Miami">University of Miami</a> has also experienced some degree of controversies, scandals and incidents which at times have led to <a href="NCAA">NCAA</a> sanctions, suspensions, and negative publicity for the university. These include a situation in 1978 where three players threw a man into a lake precipitating the resignation of coach <a href="Lou%20Saban">Lou Saban</a>, the 1991 Cotton Bowl Classic unsportsmanlike conduct giving rise to the so-called "Miami Rule", the 1995 Pell Grant scandal, and the 2005 "7th Floor Crew" rap song, described above.
1980s: Luther Campbell's "pay for play".
<a href="2%20Live%20Crew">2 Live Crew</a> member <a href="Luther%20Campbell">Luther Campbell</a> was alleged to have been behind what was referred to as a "pay-for-play" system, which involved cash rewards for acts such as scoring touchdowns and big hits, although Campbell has never donated directly to the University of Miami or its athletics department.
2006: FIU brawl.
On October 14, 2006, in the first meeting of cross-town programs, Miami and the <a href="FIU%20Panthers%20football">Florida International Golden Panthers</a> brawled after a <a href="Extra%20point">PAT</a>.
FIU cornerback Chris Smith wrestled Miami holder Matt Perelli to the ground after the kick and appeared to punch him in the chin. Another FIU cornerback, Marshall McDuffie, Jr., kicked Perelli in the head. Miami's <a href="Anthony%20Reddick">Anthony Reddick</a> swung his helmet at FIU players and Miami's <a href="Brandon%20Meriweather">Brandon Meriweather</a> kicked an FIU player. FIU's A'Mod Ned, who was injured, came onto the field and swung at Miami players with his crutches. The fight lasted just over one minute before the coaches of both teams were able to separate the players. Florida Highway Patrol state troopers and City of Miami police arrived on the field as the fight was going on and remained a visual presence on the sidelines and in the stands to prevent further fighting. The game was delayed approximately 15 to 20 minutes as the officials attempted to sort out which players were ejected and what, if any, penalty yards needed to be enforced.
The next day, 31 players from both schools were punished–18 from FIU, 13 from Miami; the Miami players were handed one-game suspensions, while the FIU players were suspended for the remainder of the season. Three Miami players were suspended indefinitely and the rest were also assigned community service work.
2002–2010: Shapiro scandal.
A <a href="Ponzi%20scheme">Ponzi scheme</a>r, convicted <a href="felony">felon</a> and former Miami booster, <a href="Nevin%20Shapiro">Nevin Shapiro</a>, claimed he used investor funds to finance donations to the University of Miami's athletic program and gave an estimated $2 million in illegal benefits to at least 72 current or former football and basketball players and coaches from 2002 to 2010. A <a href="Yahoo%21%20Sports">Yahoo! Sports</a> report alleged that Shapiro, through his donations, violated at least four major NCAA bylaws.
During the investigation of the allegations, the university self-imposed a ban on bowl participation. In October 2013, the NCAA announced that the university would lose three football scholarships in each of the next three seasons, but there would be no further bowl ban. The university became eligible again for bowl participation as of the 2013–14 season.
Documentary film.
In 2009, Miami-based media studio <a href="Rakontur">Rakontur</a> released a documentary film called "<a href="The%20U%20%28documentary%29">The U</a>", as part of <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a>'s "30 for 30" film series. The film depicts the rise of the University of Miami's football tradition throughout the 1980s and early 1990s. According to the filmmaker, the university chose not to be involved in the project, and denied access to coach Randy Shannon, Paul Dee and <a href="Edward%20T.%20Foote%20II">Tad Foote</a>, the former president of the university. The film features the rise of the UM football program in the 1980s, but also includes details related to player crime and drug usage and privileges provided to players, including <a href="Luther%20Campbell">Luther Campbell</a>'s "pay for play", in which the rap star reportedly paid UM players for major hits and plays. The film addresses the controversial and pioneering nature of the UM football program. The film was pre-screened on campus on December 10, 2009, with only two student athletes attending and televised two days later on <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a>. "The U Part 2" was also created to depict the rise and once again fall of their football program.
